Ok, maybe the Mu Shu Chicken will be better. BF unwraps the foil to get the mu shu wrappers and guess what he finds.... TORTILLAS. Yes. Actual Mexican tortillas. So I dish some filling onto my plate and try it first. It tastes like sugar. Seriously, I think the sauce was made out of simple syrup. I get a weird look on my face and so the BF grabs a bite and instantly spits it out and runs to the sink to rinse his mouth out. A tortilla couldn't have made it taste any better. 

The only thing we both actually finished was the soup. We ripped up the take out menu and I'm posting this review to remind myself to never order from here again. I thought even "bad Chinese food" was supposed to be good. I was expecting a Panda Express type meal, but instead all we got was a lot of smelly garbage. 

$40 down the drain. 

Oh- but the delivery was very fast.
author: Ali R.

description:
So many meatless meat options!!! Get the veggie wonton soup.  This place made me actually crave and appreciate Chinese Food for the first time since being vegetarian.  

Things tend to be on the very spicy side, and I like spicy, but sometimes it's a little much...so consider yourself warned.
author: Kacie O.

description:
I guess for delivery, it's ok. The hargow and and suimai were ok. The only thing that I liked was the chicken chow mein which I asked for less oil and no bean sprouts but there were some sprouts (no much so it was easy to pick out) and it was pretty oily. It was tasty though! The salt and pepper shrimp (I asked for it to be crispy and not soggy, so maybe it was my fault that it was gross) was interesting and NOT spicy at all (I asked for it to be medium in the spiciness factor), so that was pretty disappointing. The garlic noodles with chicken was pretty disgusting. 

So, the only thing that I liked was the chicken chow mein which I give 3 stars, the two dim sum items are a 2, everything else is a 1.
author: Mayana P.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant in the city! Great prices and the food is so authentic!! I'm really picky about my chicken and they have delicious white meat chicken options! Would HIGHLY recommend!
author: Jillian R.

description: I got delivery from here today and it was yummy.  My favorite item was the shrimp and eggplant roll.  Lunch specials go to 4pm and they have a good variety of options.
author: Cynthia B.

description: This is my office's go-to lunch destination when we want Chinese. Perfect place for lunch or take out. I highly recommend the meatless chicken!
author: Johnny W.

description:
I've only eaten here twice, but on both occasions I've found the food to be excellent. The location and setting is great, and the staff are friendly and cool. 

They also have a larger-than-average menu, and are the only Chinese restaurant that I've been to that offers lamb dishes. 

Highly recommended
author: Adrian H.

description: Oh man, good food.  I'd tell you to go for the Honey Walnut Prawns, but then again, everything I've had here is delicious.  Can't go wrong.
author: Jacob A.

description: Ordered some food from here and it was fast and pretty good. Highly recommend the pork buns
author: Michael R.

description: Good, cheap food in a well decorated and vibrant setting. Great dim sum as well.
author: Mario W.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Big Lantern. I've had pretty good experiences eating there, but their takeout delivery always leaves me disappointed.

As a vegetarian, I'm always happy to find places that offer fake meat, its not that I'm a huge fan of meatless chicken, but S.O. is, and it's nice when we don't have to fight over who gets to order the kung pao. My favorite dishes here are definitely the onion pancake, kung pao and veggie chow mein. As far as versatile chinese restaurants in the mission go, this is one of my favorites.
author: Allyson S.

description:
The first time I ate here (about 6 months ago) it was great. Unfortunately, it's been downhill ever since. The last experience would warrant no stars if it were possible.

I called in an order at 7:30 on a Sunday night. The woman who answered the phone was unpleasant at best. They had the wrong address associated with my phone number and she got increasingly angry when I tried to correct it. After my 5th attempt to correct the address she said she got it.

After more than an hour, I called to check on the order and they said it was on it's way and would be there in less than 10 minutes. At 9:00 it still wasn't there so I called again. Again they said 10 minutes. At 9:30 they tried to deliver it to the wrong address then called for the correct address. 

When the cold food showed up at almost 10:00 it was not at all what I ordered. In fact, I couldn't even tell what it was, other that the most foul thing I have ever smelled. It gets worse, but I'm out of time so I'll leave it at that. Long story short, the food sucks and the service is worse.
author: Amber B.

description: If I could give this place negative stars, I would. It took TWO AND A HALF HOURS to deliver some pot stickers, curry beef, and fried rice. Don't waste your time.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
This is the best Chinese take out I have had since living in San Francisco (of course I don't order out that often, nor have I tried them all, but still!). Our food came before the 45 minute ETA they gave us and was delicious. They're prices are a little more than I'd like to pay, but I firmly felt it was worth the money...even the $12 honey walnut shrimp!
I'll be back for more
author: Lauren D.

description:
I've been coming here for like 2 years, can't believe it's taken me so long to write a review!  I should start by saying that I am a meat eater, love chicken, beef, pork, lamb, on and on.  But I came here with my vegan friend years ago and we shared some meatless entrees and I kid you not, their meatless dishes are the bomb diggity!!  I seriously order their meatless versions instead of real chicken and that is saying a lot!  I've never preferred the meatless version of things and am always left wanting more out of veggie/vegan dishes, but not here!  Wish I could get their freakin' recipe.  

I should warn you though that their meatless entrees generally taste the same, not sure if the sauces are just subtly different or what.  I stick to the meatless sesame chicken...heavenly and heats up well the next day too!  I also heard they have great dim sum and good brunch on the weekends, but haven't tried it.  Also, they have fast delivery and you get free chow mein or fried rice if u order 2 entrees...can't beat that!
author: Kevin M.

description: I placed my order at 10:16pm and was told 45-75 minutes wait time. After 11:06 I checked with eat24 and they called the restaurant. They lied to the eat24 rep saying there was a lot of cops and it was preventing delivery. That it would take 10-15 minutes extra. That time also came and past, it had now been 1 hour 30 minutes (more or less)11:42pm and I called the restaurant directly. The lady was very rude, kept telling me to wait for my food. I told her it was nearing 2 hours, she said I was only 1 hour and mumbled sorry then hung up. I then contacted eat24 at 12:00am and canceled my order. This was far too long and extremely unprofessional. The delivery guy called my cell after and also knocked on my door for several minutes. From 12:08-12:16 I didn't answer because I didn't want to be charged for cold food and bad service. I wish I could rate these guys -5 stars. -_-' If only my go to place was open on Mondays, I wouldn't have this issue.
author: Jared N.

description:
Big Lantern surprised me with their friendly service and speedy delivery. 

The guy over the phone was very helpful and patient when taking my order. Their menu is very extensive which renders me not knowing what to order. So I asked the question that is forbidden at almost any Asian restaurant: "what are your most popular items?" I was ready for something like: "I don't know. It's up to you" or "everything is good" or maybe a lousy suggestion of some random dish they come up with on the spot. Instead, the guy gave me a list of like 15 dishes AND I also really appreciate that he actually gave it some thought; he was "mm-ing" between suggestions until I finally picked a dish. I literally ran to my boyfriend and told him I just talked to the nicest Asian restaurant worker ever.

Food arrived in approximately 30 minutes (give or take). I don't know if the delivery guy is the same as the order-taking guy, but he was very nice too. I live in a condo and I guess the front desk people went home, so the delivery guy couldn't get in. He called me and SANG, ~~~Big Lantern. I'm downstairs~~~ LOL. It's freezing-balls out there. Who could sing anymore?

Food was still warm. At just the right temperature to eat without burning yourself, except the soup which was still very hot. The General Chicken (one of their most popular item) was "very good" according to my boyfriend. The deep-fried battered chicken pieces seemed a bit soggy, but that's just the difference between eating at the restaurant and doing take-out. I ordered a second entree because the guy told me free fried rice if you order two entrees. I ordered the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings, not one of his recommendation but it was something my boyfriend and I adore back in our hometown. Mmm. Not so great here. Neither salty nor peppery. Topped with a ton of fried garlic and some sliced jalapeño with a hint of curry/cumin and lemon AND they're on steroids. Next time I'll stick with the guy's recommendations. The fried rice was a big fried rice (I think 26oz) and you get to pick what type of meat you want in it. Even though it was unusually dark, it didn't have a whole lot of flavor. Boyfriend said he preferred steamed rice. My chicken corn soup (without chicken) was disappointing. There was barely any corn.

Their service was definitely worth 5 stars. Their food is sub-par. But I will order delivery from them again. 

Highlights:
+ friendly service
+ speedy delivery
+ doesn't limit their delivery service to only places within walking distance; they did say they'd deliver to anywhere in SF
+ extensive vegetarian options

+/- free fried rice with your choice of meat if you order 2 entrees (not that yummy)

- sub-par Americanized Chinese food
- barely any corn in my corn soup (me sad)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Did you want meatless 'chicken' dishes? Did you want them awesome? Did you want them to be better than actual chicken? Oh you didn't? then don't come here. 

Oh you did? Great, cos there isn't a better place to get it.

Oh what's that? You want it CHEAP too? Yeah, same place. 

In short, this place rules.
author: Kevin O.

description:
I tried this place for the first time last night and it was straight amazing. The service was fast, yet friendly and both waiters were very attentive to our needs. I asked quite a few questions about the meatless items and waiter #1 answered all of them without a hint of annoyance. They also refill your water like crazy, which is good since you need eight glasses a day!

I ordered the General Meatless Chicken and let me say, IT WAS SO GOOD. Don't bother ordering anything else!!! The steamed broccoli made me feel less guilty for eating fried food but hey, if I'm really on a diet, I shouldn't be eating Chinese! Also, the portion on this dish was huge so I had another meal left to take home.

My friend ordered a chow mein dish with chicken and after she tasted mine, she said it was so much better! HAH you meat-a-saurus'!

Anyway, great service plus fast and good food is worth FIVE stars in my book. I will be returning, especially after I found out they have dim sum AND deliver?! WHAT?! Time to schedule some gym time.
author: pamela b.

description: Chinese dim sum in the Mission, need I say more.   We ordered take out and when we opened the boxes at the office, our mouths dropped wide open.  We were expecting the portions to be twice as big.  Not to mention everything was overly salty.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I'm sitting here with my two friends and they say Big Lantern sucks and anyone who rated it high to give it 3.5 stars is a fool. They are elitists. I enjoy Big Lantern, and to throw it in their faces I am writing this review.

The food might be slightly salty and oily, however, the pea sprouts are quite good. The chicken is serviceable. Combined with the low price and considering there are always tables available I find them to be worthy of this five star rating.

Good day, sir.
author: Justin K.

description: Big lantern is very good but can be a little hit or miss.  I like that they have a lot of vegetarian choices but I'm not crazy about all of them.  I love all the things they make with meatless chicken but I haven't been as delighted by the other meatless stuff.  I haven't been crazy about the stuff on the dim sum menu but other people really like them so maybe it's just me.  They deliver and that's awesome but we haven't gotten delivery from them since we discovered golden kim tar.  We went there for Chrismas eve this year and I liked it but I kept thinking that the only reason we went there was because so many other places were closed and that I'd wished we had done better.
author: Joseph C.

description:
This is our go-to delivery place for Chinese in the city. They are always on time and the food is always in great shape when it arrives!  They have online delivery (a BIG plus) and the food always arrives within 30 minutes to Hayes Valley.

The food itself is nothing fancy, but is quite tasty. None of that syrupy nonsense... Just some simple Chinese American food! 

Today's order:
Hot and Sour Soup: Lots of flavor. We ordered medium hot and it was quite spicy. Good for clearing the sinuses :)
Chicken Moo Shu: Really nice flavors, a little greasy, but hit the spot.
Garlic eggplant: This dish rocked. Totally delicious! Certainly ordering this one again!
author: Evren O.

description:
ordered delivery and got veggie fried rice, hot and sour soup, and the vegetarian egg rolls with meatless chicken.

all was A-ok! 

I actually LOVED the soup
author: Osh J.

description:
I am a big fan of eat24hours.com, and as a result -- became a big fan of Big Lantern (as it is rated fairly high on the site).  I would never actually GO to the restaurant for a meal, but take-out?  Definitely.

Big Lantern is one of the few restaurants that deliver dim sum.  Though it's not the best per se, it's simply convenient and decent in both taste and price.

My personal favorite is the dim sum combo -- which includes 3 shrimp dumpings, 3 pork siu mais, and 3 BBQ pork buns (all for $7.95).  Once in awhile, I'll "splurge" on the half-order of Peking duck (which is reasonably priced at $13.95).  It's rich and fatty -- just how I like it!  Their buns are also the "silky smooth" kind (which I prefer).

As I've emphasized, Big Lantern is great -- but just for those lazy nights in where delivery is the best option.
author: Judy C.

description: We recently ordered from Big Lantern for delivery.  . . to keep a long (very long) story short we ordered expecting delivery between 45m-75m - well over 120m (aka 2 Hours) later we still had no food, no update from the restaurant and an offensive call with the manager when asking for an update.  When it finally arrived, delivered by a similarly rude delivery person, the bag was full of leaked food (Szechuan sauce and chicken everywhere).  Hoping for the best we still opened it up and were treated to cold and completely inedible food that looked and tasted like it had come from a day old dumpster . . . and as a result ended right back in one.  We weren't offered a refund, discount or so much as an apology . . . so save yourself the wait, the aggravation and the taste buds and order from somewhere (really anywhere) else.
author: Mirja T.

description: Yea I ordered food tonight @ 7:30pm. . . Waited till 9 to call. Got some slack about I'm gonna call my driver. So I insisted I'd be calling back to get a time frame. . . I did and the guy never even called his delivery driver, till I called backed, rather curt. . Of course 5 minutes. . . Guy showed up, quick fast tried to get me to sign, without going over the bill. As they have pulled fast one's before. . ( Bill not the same as Beyond Menu Total). So I looked and this guy stepped up in my door frame. Trying to bull his way out of there. Gave the food and ran off. It was wrong once I checked the copy he said he filled out. ( Off by $1.19). But still. Quite a little delivery scam. Considering Free Delivery.  On a $19.12 Total. . . Total bunk artist. And food was cold as hell. . . . Gonna have to say this is my last. As the Delivery Service has faltered the last few months. Ending in the last two times same stuff. . . I have been a customer since the beginning. In the Noe Valley Area. Maybe over ten years. Since they opened. And this stretched has done it for me. Probably better health wise anyway to skipped the Chinese food. But if I want a fix. Diamond heights and 24th is hot and ready to go. . . Besides a little drive never hurt anyone. . . . Done.
author: Joe R.

description:
I am loathe to write a bad review of any place in SF that sells reasonably priced vegetarian chicken dishes... HOWEVER. I ordered the moo shoo meatless chicken, and they actually delivered tortillas with it instead of pancakes.

YEAH.

YOU HEARD ME.

TORTILLAS.

MEXICAN TORTILLAS.

uuuuuuunacceptable!!!!!
author: Emily H.

description:
I probably would never go to this restaurant by myself but a coworker is leaving and we reserved this place for our last Friday dinner together (for a group of 11 people). 

Here are the good points:
Budget spending and my ordering of Peking duck is decent! The half Peking duck is only $13.5.  It came with four small bum for wrapping--when I say small, it is really small. But it kinds of mimicks what a traditional Peking duck should be like. With the diced cucumber and green onion, I think this dish is a steal. 

Other food that I've seen and tasted from my co-workers' orders: Mangolian beef and Mushu pork were a bit too sweet. The texture of the meatless chicken was no comparison to a good tofu dish, but I am not vegetarian so I can't understand why people like it so much.  The green onion pancake was A-OK. 

Can't say this is a bad experience but I prefer to go to other restaurants where I can eat something more healthy.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Usually I like to cook, but the other day I home late.  There was nothing in the fridge, and I was too lazy to go to the store.  Luckily my neighborhood offers plenty of take-out options; I picked this place, which was just down the street.  I had never eaten there, but I was comforted by the fact that it's usually pretty busy inside.  The Yelp reviews said it specialized in something called "meatless chicken."  It was the most popular thing on the menu. 

The first time I ordered it, the meatless chicken came in brown cubes.  The texture was so meat-like and it tasted so chicken-y that I thought they had made a mistake with my order.  Perhaps I was a little naive, but I had eaten plenty of similarly advertised meatless items before.  So befuddled was I over the mystery meat's identity that I couldn't finish it.    

A few days later, I was still so uncertain over my meatless chicken experience that I decided I needed to order it again.  This time I ordered the meatless chicken as lunch special with a sesame sauce.  (Btw- lunch special is a great deal - it's cheap and it's huge.)  The meatless chicken was totally different this time - deep fried and smothered in the sesame sauce to the degree that my taste buds could detect no fake chicken-y taste at all..  Reassured of the product's meatlessness and encouraged by the fact that it was deep fried in fatty goodness, I enjoyed the artificial meat much more the second time around.  You can read more about the slippery and subjective boundaries between meatless distaste and delight here, and also see some pics.  http://homogastronomicus.blogspot.com/2013/02/a-matter-of-haut-gout.html

I also really liked the onion pancake that comes with a peanut dipping sauce and the chive dumplings.  But when I looked at the menu this time I didn't see the dumpings.  I'm concerned that they might have been a special.
author: India M.

description:
I would love to give Big Lantern a 4-5 stars. 
The food is super good, but that ONE waiter is a super grumpy guy! 

I live a block away from this place. A while ago I ordered for delivery and I had never had an issue, he made me go pick up!! I mean I ALWAYS give a good tip! he said "delivery? you live close, come pick up" I was like WHAT? you serious?? I had friends over... I just went I didn't want to argue with the guy... 

I also eat there at times for lunch and he still at times is a sour ball... The other waiters are cool, but this one is not that cool... but when he's our waiter he's not lucky with the tip...
author: Claudia G.

description:
Eh. 

I figured because they served dim sum, it must be somewhat authentic.

Apparently not.

Nothing was terrible, but it was all pretty typical Americanized Chinese food drenched in the same sauce regardless of the dish. There's better American Chinese food in Chinatown.

The service, both in terms of friendliness and attentiveness were certainly above average for a Chinese restaurant, as was the beer and wine selection.

The only reason I'd come back is if I had a vegetarian friend that wanted Chinese food, as the vegetarian dishes were probably the strongest.
author: Mark A.

description:
Pop quiz:

If you're me, and you order delivery from Big Lantern, what does that say about you?

A) You're lazy, because Big Lantern takes roughly 30 seconds to walk to.

B) You're really hungover, and it's too painful to move more than 20 feet away from the couch (where you're inevitably watching some sort of entertaining TV on DVD).

C) You justify being lazy and/or really hungover and ordering delivery by remembering that Big Lantern's delivery is free, and the delivery guys never seem to judge you (bless their hearts). 

D) Any/all of the above.

P.S. The answer is D, in case that wasn't obvious.

P.P.S. Big Lantern's basil meatless chicken with brown rice is supremely tasty.
author: Anna G.

description:
While on a road trip w/ my Boys and Girls Club high school group I'm involved with, we stayed a night at the Columbia Park Clubhouse. We were hungry and asked them what was good in the neighborhood that could seat 13, and they took us out to Big Lantern Chinese. I'd say it was pretty successful. It had a great feel to in the slightly small restaurant. We ordered all types of different foods, but it wasn't your ordinary plate, they gave us a bunch of different big bowls of Orange Chicken, Kung Pao, Beijing Beef, etc. It had a hella nice traditional family dinner feels to it, plus the food was super good. I just wish it wasn't so small. I felt super squished the whole time. They had Tv's w/ ESPN on, so it's great if your sports fanatic.
MY favorite part about Big Lantern was the area. It seemed like a really cool community, and everybody knows each other.
Good people. Good Food. Great area. If that's all you care about, then this joint's a win.
author: Biciok K.

description:
The Pros:
1.) This is a great place for  vegetarians who want all the choices everyone else has (so long as they can eat gluten) and meat eaters who have just gone veg who are prolonging their relapse back into meat. Almost every dish you can think of can be found in a veg version with fake meat. I really like the General's Meatless Chicken but the truth of the matter is my stomach does not.
2.) Take out has always shown up for me when they say they're going to show up.
3.) They're open late.
4.) I know from experience they can be talked into delivering outside their normal delivery zone if only you spend enough.
5.) Service is usually attentive, even if it gets busy.
6.) Most of the dim sum options are pretty yummy. The dumplings are usually pretty darn good.
7.) They have a huge menu but not so large that you feel so overwhelmed you want to give up the second you see it.
8.) Dining room is clean and looks nice.

The Cons and The Questionable Stuff:
1.) I cook more authentic Chinese food... and I'm an American Mayan-European mix.
2.) You may get better food than me. Or you may get worse. Flip a coin to measure the consistency of quality at this restaurant. They seem to have some standby dishes though that they never mess up. The chow mein so far for me has been one of these. It has a lot of crispy, fresh veggies  though in all honest it's a little greasy.
3.) Truth be told, everything here is kind of a bit too greasy.
4.) Tortillas are always yummy. Well, actually, not quite always. They are not so tasty when topped with the gelatinous gravy from this place. This is the way I envision my Mexican American grandmother cooking Chinese food, except much lighter and healthier.
5.) Sometimes (but not always) their fried rice tastes a lot like how I used to make fried rice when I was five. I just added soy sauce every time the rice started to stick to the bottom of the wok. The result is very, very salty rice.
6.) The spring rolls are a gelatinous greasy mess. *gag*
7.) Delivery, while on time, is still so slow you might actually end up getting so hungry that you eat before they get there.
8.) This one of very, very few places I've ever been to where we've been asked to leave our table the instant we paid the bill. I get that they may want the table for someone else but this comes across as tacky.
9.) Beware the leaky take out containers!
author: A J.

description:
5 stars for  friendly service. 

2 stars for bad dim sum. No matter what we ordered it was really not up to par with good SF places. The rice noodle shrimp was mushy and overcooked. The shu mai seemed to be old and have an after taste.  I dint even try the last three dishes we got. 
I wasnt impressed by anything and dont think i'll ever go back. 
Shame, it would have been wonderful to have a great dim sum in the mission.
author: Tasha A.

description:
Ok, I am medium on this place. They deliver, and quickly - which is awesome. And they have a large menu - also awesome. The food however, was not that awesome. I ordered:

Crab cheese puff - super yummy
Veggie spring rolls - medium
Chicken dumpling - eh
Shrimp dumpling - did not eat because I felt like it would be another eh
Vegetable dumpling - eh
Pork siu mai - eh
Curry puff - I actually spit it out
Foil wrapped chicken - delicious
Stuffed mushroom - medium

...And yes, that was for one - so I like a choice, so what??
author: Kristin N.

description: I normally avoid eating at any Chinese place that doesn't come with a high recommendation. I also have a hard time picking the "right" thing off the menu. However, I finally made the right call at Big Lantern. The vegetable potstickers as an appetizer were great, but the five spice sesame meatless chicken was absolutely incredible.
author: Kyle B.

description:
The food is ok - typical Americanized-Chinese.  They do offer up a surprisingly large dim sum selection for a delivery place, and while they aren't great, they are decent.  Similarly, they have a very large faux-meat selection, and I always enjoy their general Tcho's meatless chicken.

However, there are significant issues when trying to order on the phone:

1.  The environment where they take orders is extremely loud, and many of the folks manning the phones have a limited command of English.  This makes ordering from them *extremely* frustrating, as you have to essentially scream and repeat yourself many, many times in order to make yourself understood - ordering delivery is supposed to alleviate stress, not create it.

2.  Most of the time, the food is not packaged carefully, and there is almost always significant leakage when you order dishes that have a lot of sauce.

3.  Prices are somewhat expensive, although portions are also sizable, and with 2 dishes you get a free fried rice or vegatable lo mein.

Of these criticisms, #1 is the most significant, and can make ordering delivery a truly unpleasant experience.
author: Daniel M.

description:
OK... so get this.  I used to LOVE the Yum Yum House, especially when they would come to my friend's apartment and answer in the loudest shrill "YUM YUM!!" when we'd ask "Who is it?"  They are, of course, no more.  However, thanks to the reviews on this site I read that BL were the same owners!  

So I said "F" the menu.  I'm just gonna call and order our favorites, things that only Yum Yum could do well.  They had Salt and Pepper Prawns, 5 Flavor Chicken, Pork Fried Rice, and Veggie Potstickers.  The guys paused, started speaking chinese to the guys in the back, came back to the phone and was like no problem.  They don't even have that stuff on the big lantern menu [well some of it].  So that was cool. At the end of the call, he said we also got a free Low Mein, JUST LIKE YUM YUM.  

I will morn the death of great Chinese Cuisine no more...  Thanks Yelp Reviewers.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of this Chinese restaurant.  I usually get delivery since their service is exceptionally speedy.  My food is hot and delish.

Their orange chicken dish is exceptionally tasty.  Its a great blend of sweet and spicy - they even leave the chili peppers in so it adds to the spicy kick.

All in all this place is great, especially for deliveries.  I highly recommend it to all my friends on Yelp!
author: Ryan K.

description:
Vegan dim sum?! Sign me up!

The dumpling wrappers are a little thick and sticky, but after attempting to make vegan har gau at home, I'm not going to complain. This isn't fine dining; it's comfort food. The taro puffs are delightfully greasy and delicious. The cheong fun wrappers are nicely soft and slightly chewy. Half of the vegetarian options seem to be filled with the same cabbage-mushroom concoction (maybe some lily flowers, too?), but it's tasty enough to be passable.

We also had the crispy fried salt and pepper tofu, which had a really good texture, but could use more garlic and hot peppers. 

They also serve the dim sum all week! No waiting in line on a Sunday morning here.

Overall, not the most delicate, award winning dim sum, but it sure beats trying to make it yourself, or just eating several servings of the one vegetable option a conventional tea house might have (if you're lucky).
author: mel c.

description:
I love eating here, and I love their takeout. Never a disappointment. Last time Becca and I went there, we both ordered desserts and drinks and left with a bill around 20 bucks! I always get the orange chicken, but since she was getting the meatless orange, I decided to go with the kung pao. It was amazing! We ordered cute little desserts (peach buns and mango pudding) for the first time ever, and it was great too. 

LUNCH MENU ROCKS!
author: Lauren R.

description: This place is amazeballs. I've been a (mostly) vegetarian for 5 years and the thing I've missed the most was sesame chicken. No more! This place has *such* amazing vegetarian food, which goes way beyond the usual vegetable-based dish most other Chinese joints offer. Prices aren't bad and the food's genuinely tasty. Also, they deliver! Who could ask for more?!
author: Amy S.

description: It's food was great, but delivery sevice took for ever, took three hours. When i called after I asked one question and they would answer but hung up neary right after. I had to place two sepereate orders until they actually recieved it.
author: Michelle L.

description:
This place is OK!  Ok?  The dishes are made with all-natural ingredients, like FOOD.  The rice was white and fluffy and the vegetarian chicken as chewy and soy-ish as could be hoped.  So I did have to add liberal quantities of red chili sauce with that tiny spoon to give it some flavor but that's OK!  

It was not expensive, the food arrived quickly, and best of all --by the time I finished my plate, I no longer felt hungry!  Mission accomplished.
author: Molly T.

description:
Why isn't there an option to give less than a star or negative stars!?

Big lantern?  More like Big douchebag.

I ordered from this place a couple of weeks ago because it was my roommates birthday.  I wanted to take her out for dinner but she didn't want to go out because of a long day at work so we ordered Chinese from this place that she suggested.

I called them and ordered whatever looked good.
- Sesame meatless chicken
- Vegetable Chow Mein
- Lemon meatless chicken
- Yum Yum Eggplant

The guy on the phone informed me that we would get a free order of fried rice with our order which was nice.

The order came pretty fast and the food wasn't that bad.  The lemon meatless chicken and the chow mein was the best.

The worst part was I think the food gave me the worst stomach ache.  After waiting it out for the next couple of days I ate some of the left overs and had the same problem again.  I composted the rest because I didn't trust it.

Now today, my roommate tried placing an order with them.  First think he asks her is "Do you have a $35 order?"

After she informed him that we were only ordering about $18 he said that it wasn't enough.  He said that we lived too far and he couldn't just walk our order over and they would have to drive.

Umm...don't ALL delivery places usually drive orders over?  Who is the wackjob that is sending their employees walking all over San Francisco?

AND their website and menu doesn't say ANYTHING about a $35 minimum.  Actually your website says free delivery and the online ordering system says an $18 minimum.  if you SAY 18 dollar minimum you can't tell your customers that you are not buying enough food because you are "too far" and then demand that they order more.  Besides 3.5 miles is not considered "too far" by the way.

The guy was super rude on the phone and we didn't even want to bother giving them our service.

I don't support a business that is that unfriendly with their customers and demand that they purchase more food.  We decided to order from Ken's Kitchen instead.

Don't bother to waste your time with this place.  The food wasn't that great and you'll probably get sick like I did.
author: Kameron K.

description:
I've eaten here twice now and this is the kind of Chinese food that I would crave back in the days of eating meat. Their meatless chicken is fried and is really yummy. I've had both the sweet and sour as well as the 5-spice chicken and both are flavored quite well.
The chow fun was incredibly salty tonight and I suppose I could've asked for light soy sauce.

When it comes to service, I don't ask for much. I just want my glass of water to be filled when it is empty, and I want the waiter to be attentive when needed.
A few of the guys working here seemed to be friendly but there was one who seemed a little annoyed. Perhaps his night wasn't going swell but I would've liked to see a little more effort from him to attend to my friend and I.

The two stars is for how gross I feel after eating this kind of food. When I got home I drank some Mona Vie to help me not feel healthier. That stuff has a ton of antioxidants in it and costs $45 a bottle.
This kind of food is great when you're really missing the old junk food you had as a kid, but for me, I only miss that kind of food about once a year.

Also, I don't like that there aren't meal combos.

If you're sensitive to salt, then you should definitely avoid this place.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Good vegetarian options. I have only used delivery, but they are always quick and the food is good. Their mu-shu comes with tortilla instead of rice paper and is so over steamed and stuck together it is generally  not useable, but the veggies are fresh so that makes up for it.  

Their meatless chicken salad and Meatless General chicken is addictive!
author: Nana W.

description: I ordered Big Lantern for delivery and tracked it online. After about 5 minutes I got an email saying my food would arrive in 90 minutes. 145 minutes later I was on the phone with the manager trying to figure out where my food was. I had also added special instructions to my apartment because it's a little confusing. Finally I figured out that my food was "on the way" (the manager didn't give me anything more specific than that). When the driver finally arrived he called me and it turned out he was several blocks away, despite my specific instructions. I kept trying to explain to him where I was, and he kept saying "I'll wait here, see you soon". After calling him 3 times I said "wait there" and just walked (which took a further 10 minutes). When I finally got my food back to my apartment it was cold, dry, chewy, and awful. This was the most frustrating experience I have had with delivery and I will not be getting food from Big Lantern again.
author: Noa B.

description: Everything in here is nice the customer service the food I love the Thai ice tea and the lunch specials also the imperial rolls
author: Ricky L.

description: Great dim sum at amazing prices!  I especially recommend the steamed pork buns.
author: Lucy L.

description:
I love the food here, among the best Chinese food in the city. I really do. I live in Chinatown, and Big Lantern is seriously better than most of the places that are around me. 

The only reasons it's not five star has to do with the fact that they've really kept me waiting a couple times for delivery, but I do live in North Beach, so it's pretty far away. The last time the food arrived late, I called up, and they were apologetic and understanding. Which was pretty awesome of them, and I appreciate it.
author: Neal P.

description:
Absolutely ridiculous.  I will never order from this restaurant ever again.  

I placed an order over 2 hours ago and still have not received the delivery.   Literally four calls and four repeated promises of the food arriving "in 10 mins" is the best you can expect from this place.  

Ugh.  Definitely order here if you are looking for a headache, patchy service, and cold food.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Probably not anyone's definition of authentic Chinese food. And I know I'll get a lot of judgement from the San Francisco Chinese-American community on my high rating for this place, but you must know that it comes from a very subjective perspective (as opposed to my other reviews): I live nearby and am a vegetarian. 

Location: Fabulous location, right on 16th St. between Valencia and Guerrero. Tons to do before and after eating and accessible to absolutely anyone and everyone.

Space: Looks like most other Chinese restaurants in they city. (Except Chinatown....you never know what to expect in that area.)

Ambiance: The strangest crowd of people. People from the area. Hipsters. People who just want Chinese food and don't know that this place emphasizes vegetarian dishes. This is more like the place you order from twice a week when you don't want to cook and are tired of Mac N' Cheese. Or the place you stumble on after a couple of beers at Delirium.

Service: I love the service here! It's absolutely horrible. I believe every single complaint about the service written in all the other reviews. But that's part of the whole experience of eating at ethnic places. If you walk into a real Mexican restaurant, none of this Aztec Taqueria bullshit, all the servers will shit-talk you in Spanish in the back. We just have different views of service in other countries. So just order your food, eat it and be prepared to have a little argument with the waiter or waitress every once in a while. 

Food/Drink: The food is good and priced well. Obviously it is not Chinatown price: quality ratio, but it's as close as you'll get in the area. I love the greasy-ness and VAST menu. Tons and tons of vegetarian options, which is why I am giving this place a 4 star. And they deliver until 10!

Overall: Great food, interesting experiences and fabulous location.... plus vegetarian love, you couldn't ask for anything more from a Tuesday night of hunger and laziness.
author: SF N.

description:
There are very few things I really, truly hate in life.  One is doing my laundry.  Man, that sucks.  Another is rubbery chicken, which is unfortunately all too common in delivery Chinese food.  My world definitely changed for the better, though, when I picked up a Chinese delivery menu left outside my door and saw that the place offered an "all white meat" option for an extra couple bucks.  Though that chicken ended up being subpar, I realized that asking for all white meat chicken is a viable option from most delivery places if you're willing to pay.

I've since done so at a couple different Chinese food places, but Big Lantern is far and away the winner in terms of the big, juicy chunks of chicken breast they include in everything I order.  My go-to is the Mongolian chicken, which will actually taste spicy if I insist I can handle it, and the Kung-Pao chicken, which definitely does not skimp on the peanuts, bell peppers and zucchini.  

Fried rice has also been one of my favorite foods since I was a kid and is kind of hard to screw up, but Big Lantern does it right for sure.  I get veggie egg fried rice, because unlike the all white meat chicken I order, the beef and pork are too chewy for my taste, meaning that "combination" rice isn't an option.  I'm totally good with the veggie fried rice, though.  It comes with tiny chopped up pieces of zucchini, broccoli, regular peas (something I usually eat around), snow peas (something I usually and inexplicably DON'T eat around), and egg.  And LOTS of soy sauce, just the way Mama J. cooked it for me when I was a kid and would freeze single servings in Ziploc bags to microwave as after-school snacks.

Big Lantern is also super fast with the delivery.  They always estimate around 45 minutes, definitely standard in the city, but I would say about half the time, someone's on my doorstep in under 25 minutes!  Woo.
author: Christy J.

description:
I've eaten in and have ordered delivery from here... always good! Definitely the best vegetarian selection that I have seen for Chinese food ANYWHERE. Lots of tofu/veggie and meatless chicken options.

I personally really like the meatless orange chicken or the general chicken... bomb!

The delivery is relatively fast, when I ate in the atmosphere was cool... went there after yoga one time. 

The chow mein is kinda weird. I can't put my finger on it, but there's something different about it. It's not bad necessarily.
author: Liane V.

description: I typically order through Eat24.  Last few deliveries have been way over 90 minutes, food spilled all over the bag, and this last time they claimed they didn't get my order.  Too much hassle.  no thanks.
author: Lindsey F.

description: This hidden gem may look like a dive from the outside, particularly considering the barely legible sign above the door which faintly announces that this establishment is, indeed, the "Big Lantern".  Notwithstanding the shoddy window dressing and not-much-to-speak-of interior, the food itself is excellent.  The fried rice was some of the best I've had, and the dim sum (we selected the variety option) was excellent.  The prices were very reasonable as well, increasing the overall value.  It's also just around the corner from Four Barrel, so you can get in the obligatory coffee stop while you're in the Mission.
author: Sam V.

description:
I ordered the pan fried noodles with beef last night and I think this takes the cake as far as noodles are concerned. I'm always weary about pan fried noodles because if they don't give you enough sauce, you're left with crunchy dry twigs. Big Lantern is appropriately generous with their sauce, as well as with their meat and vegetables. Huge portion - will serve as my dinner for the next 3 nights. 

+1 for their dumplings. Always amazing. Always get them.
author: Susan L.

description:
I don't know if it's even worth one star.  I placed on order to them through Eat24hours.com.  I have used this website loads of times and had been really happy with the chinese place I usually ordered from but wanted to try something different. 

After an hour of waiting, I called them to ask what had happened to my order.  He could not find it anywhere on the system and firstly suggested the order had not gone through - even though I had a confirmed email.  He then went of to check, to come back and tell me that I the website should have rung through to confirm & that they hadn't - did I still want the order??.....that would be a no!

This situation seemed strange to me and I had never had this problem before & was worried my card would get charged despite cancelling the order over the phone.  The person on the phone said that they had not charged the card.  I just wanted to clarify this with the person on the phone and wanted to know what would happend incase I was (reasonable I thought!).  The person on the phone then decided that I must be stupid and not heard him the first time and repeated that it hadn't been charged...Ii let him know that I understood that but it wasn't what I was asking.  

This went back and forth for a while until I just mentioned that as a customer I didn't need to be spoken to the way I was & that he was not listening to his customer.  In my experience you should always listen to the customer, then they won't get pissed off and give you a crappy review without having even tried your food!

I contacted the website directly and they confirmed my what I had already thought - my order was placed, they rang and confirmed two minutes later with the restaurant, restaurant didn't put my order through.  

Moral to this long winded review........LISTEN to your customer and don't assume they are idiots and won't check on you. If you forgot to process the order then just admit it!  That's all I ask

(in the process of writing this review, I placed another order with Red Jade and have just had it delivered in about 15minutes)
author: Danae R.

description: Really really good. I've only been here once but i want to keep coming back. As a vegetarian i'm in good hands here and the servers are really nice people. love it.
author: Tim R.

description:
Big Lantern's lunch specials come with soup and a salad and cost between $4-$6. 

I'm a huge fan of the General Meatless Chicken, and the Eggplant and Prawns.

Also, they're a regular winner of the Top 100 Chinese Food Restaurants in the country.
author: Matt C.

description:
Lured in by George

Not sure how many others were mislead by George. George previously worked at the very much enjoyed " Yum Yum House" Restaurant that was located on Valencia Street @ 17th Street.  Well as many of us loyal customers know. Their lease was up- the business abruptly closed. No warning, no note left left for us, only a forwarded telephone number with an impost er at the other end. Anyway I went to Red La tern to check out the new location. Inside George greeted me & one other waiter was there. I was told EVERYONE, including the cooks moved to Red La tern and was reassured the food hadn't change. Well not only I but other frequenters immediately saw in the presentation and tasted in the food the disappointing difference. I & others gave Red La tern a few more shots with negative results. 

After much searching for another trusted worth my money place to enjoy Chinese food. A friend happen to recognize the food deliverer for Yum Yum House. Well it turns out that the owner of Yum Yum House (who also is the chef) & George had a bad falling out when the expiration of the lease was going to occur. They obviously split up. George along with a few others left Yum Yum House & went to Red La tern & forwarded Yum Yum House telephone number to take over customers. 

After that long discussion its been learned that the Chef and many of the
YUM YUM HOUSE staff RELOCATED TO
1825 DIVISADERO STREET in SF Between Bush & Pine Streets. New name of Restaurant is YUM YUM HUN AN. 

I hope many of the happy customers of Yum Yum House go and check out Yum Yum Hun an. They certainly am to please us- the customer!!
author: J F.

description:
Utterly unassuming in person, but the best vegetarian Chinese I've had in the entire country. Their meatless chicken is a home run: firm enough to mimic perfectly the consistency of white meat, yet soft enough to soak up more of the sauce than real chicken. Their General (Gao) Meatless Chicken and Kung Pao Meatless Chicken were our go-to dishes for over a year. Great hot & sour soup too. Why do so many other Chinese restaurants on the West Coast leave out the hot or the sour?

Run, don't walk. Or better yet, get delivery.
author: Eric W.

description: I've only ordered in from Big Lantern.  I found them on Grub Hub and decided to give them a try because my usual place was closed.  Big Lantern's menu, food quality, and prep is far better than the typical Chinese delivery.  They have an extensive menu with unique items I've not seen elsewhere.  They are my new standard for Chinese delivery.
author: Eddie C.

description: This restaurant makes me wish I lived in San Francisco.  Easily the best sweet n sour pork I have ever had in my life.  We also had some decent dim sum there and the potstickers were good.  I find myself craving this chinese food despite only eating there one time
author: David G.

description: Prices are too high considering competition in SF....atmosphere is not enhanced by the poor lighting and static of a television in the background.  Have eaten here multiple times and always feel ripped off afterward.  My suggestion is that prices should be 1 to 2 dollars less to be competitive with equivalent venues in the neighborhood.
author: Dav G.

description: Vegetarian Orange Chicken is all I order. I've tried a couple of other appetizers and nothing really stands out but the orange chicken is consistently delicious.
author: Taisha R.

description:
Having an open kitchen in restaurant design has been in vogue for the past couple of decades.  The theory, as I understand it, is to allow the customer to delight in watching the talented chefs as they work their culinary magic.  My experience is that more often than not, you only catch glimpses of cooks who routinely carry out their duties with mechanically uninspired movement.

Big Lantern uncovered the secret as to why restaurants opened up their kitchens in the first place.  The man preparing our food was like a samurai... only of the Chinese chef variety instead of a Japanese warrior.  Otherwise exactly the same.  His assistant would stock the cart with ingredients while he deftly wielded his large wok over a raging fire, throwing ingredients into the mix and tossing them high into the air.  Pure artistry.

The results were tasty.  They weren't the exactly the height of culinary perfection.  I'd rank it somewhere in the range of PF Chang's but cheaper and with considerably less pretentiousness.  Oh, they deliver too.
author: Christopher K.

description:
The really nice thing when you're ordering a super compley, allery issue delivery meal is when you get someone on the line that actually seems to care about what you are saying. I mean, it's really that simple. So this guy took A LOT of time with us to get it right. We ordered for delivery:

Celiac
Fried Tofu
Vegetable Fried Rice (no soy sauce)
Garlic Eggplant (spicy, no soy sauce, with corn starch, salt and pepper ok, whew, oil... did I miss something?)

Picky Vegetarian:
Mu Shu Meatless Chicken (no mushrooms)
Vege and Meatless Chicken Egg Rolls

Order came to 34.00, with tip 44.00

AND IT GOT DELIVERED IN 23 minutes!!! (I live on 10th and mission)

The food is delicious, delicious. I'm stoked. And they got all of the allergy stuff right but, they did the fried tofu as an entree. That might have been my fault, definitely added to the price. We'll be back!
author: Freud R.

description:
Cheap, fast, delivery. But I had a really bad experience this one time last summer when my then man-candy and I got really fucked up and MSG-sick and I will never order from them again. But you can. 

Original review:

The vegetarian mu shu was pretty good & the fake sesame chicken was some of the best fake meat Chinese I have had in a long time (I very much miss VP 2 in NYC). I ordered the egg tarts but once I got them I realized that what I really wanted was a cream puff and I didn't really know what egg tarts were. But I ate them. And they were good despite the fact that I could taste the shortening. Alas. I need a picture dictionary, I swear.
author: Maria D.

description:
In our neighborhood we get bombarded with take out restaurant flyers/menus every week, but on one windy, cold and foggy night in San Francisco (like every other night) we were craving Chinese food and took a chance on Big Lantern (whose flyer was actually rubber banded to our neighbor's doorknob). 

I can honestly say that the food has been hot and delicious, and they are always quick to deliver. It's been nice to have a Chinese take-out restaurant that is reliable.

1. Sesame Cold Noodle Salad - double yum
2. Snow Peas and Lily Bud with Prawn (never knew what Lily Bud were, but double yum too)
3. Kung Pao Chicken (we've tried some pretty scary KPC in our time, but this is pretty darned good)
4. Salmon w/ Asparagus (pleasantly surprised how good it is, and we didn't even mind the smell that happens after one eats Asparagus)

I do have to admit we live fairly close (Mission/Dolores Park/Market Street area), and we still haven't actually been to the restaurant, but will continue to make this our Chinese take-out of choice.

MA
author: Mickey A.

description:
This place has very decent Chinese food. The meats are flavorful and it's not too drenched in juices and sauces like other places. The real perk is that they deliver! This place has saved my life many a time when I've found an empty fridge (and a lazy body) late at night.

Try it out, it's great.
author: Masha S.

description:
The best selection of veggie dim sum in my 'hood, as far as I know. I also highly recommend the broccoli with ginger sauce, the veggie potstickers, and the vegetable chow fun, which was some of the best I've ever had.

Also, this is something you may not think is important, but it SO is. The food reheats perfectly. Like the container they use is compartmentalized, and perfect for microwave steaming, where the rice still is fluffy and delicious. SO important.
author: Sharon T.

description:
I haven't actually been to the Big Lantern in person, so this review is for their delivery.  Quick, cheap, tasty, veggie, and open late with free delivery.  It doesn't get much easier than this.

Juicy doesn't even like Chinese food and since we've started ordering from Big Lantern, she asks me at least once a week to put in an order for the spicy fried rice and some kind of meatless chicken.  She says the best thing she makes for dinner is reservations, but I'm thinking that togo orders are a close second.
author: SteveTwentyThree S.

description:
I just called this restaurant for take out and spoke with the rudest person ever!  I couldn't believe it.  I finally hung up because there's no way I'm ordering from a place where it's employees treat their customers poorly.   I'd give it zero stars if I could.  

When I was trying to order the guy kept cutting me off telling me to just hurry up and order.  All I said was that I wanted mustard sauce with my fried wontons and he kept interrupting me as I was ordering.  I knew exactly what I was ordering and wasn't indecisive.  Such a shame, really - there's so much restaurants in SF - places can't afford to treat customers like that and expect them to put up with it.
author: Jackie P.

description:
When the check came my dawg and I starting laughing. $11.23 for both of us to eat. Damn Big Lantern, you treat'n me hella fine. Rice~Soup included. Back up !!!   What, what, what, what !!!! 

Ginger Onion Lamb
Kung Pao Beef
author: Joe G.

description:
I've ordered delivery twice from Big Lantern, and will definitely order again. All the menu items I've tried (vegetable chow mien, pork buns, won ton soup, snow pea chicken, vegetable pot stickers) have been excellent. The leftovers are great the next day.

The delivery service is not super fast, so make sure to order 45-60 minutes before you're actually going to be hungry!

My only complaint (that has been echoed by others on Yelp who ordered for delivery) is the poorly sealed sauce containers that slosh around in the bag. Both times I've ordered, I've had to immediately triage all my food containers, rushing them to the nearest kitchen counter, wrapping everything in paper towels and getting it all AWAY from any table with a white tablecloth on it.

Even with the packaging issues, the food is totally worth it!
author: Heather N.

description:
False advertising. The lanterns are mid-sized. 

The food, however, is tasty for Chinese food in the Mission, which mostly ranges from downright disgusting to mildly nauseating. I appreciate the extensive "meatless" menu and that almost everything can be made to accommodate that preference. I generally get basil chicken or tofu, hot and sour soup, steamed vegetables, and some brown rice. Under 20 bucks (depending on time of day - the lunch menu is cheaper) and can last me for a few meals, depending on the current state of my tapeworm (he recommends the taro puffs and kung pao tofu).  

I have never experienced the delivery, but I have experienced the phone manners of one guy in particular, who is just a PLEASURE TO TALK TO.  Actually, he is quite rude, which is why I now call and insist on hearing IN DEPTH DESCRIPTIONS of EACH and EVERY menu item, just for giggles. The guy that suggested to "kill with kindness" has never been to Mid-Size Lantern. 

Whenever I go to pick up, the attitude dwindles and they're all relatively nice and efficient.
author: haley d.

description:
I had an amazing General Meatless Chicken here. Got the lunch special to go. Came piping hot with a side of rice and soup and lots of food: ~$7. One of the most delicious chinese dishes I've ever had, and I don't usually like fake meat dishes. The inside looked quite nice as well; not your typical dingy chinese place.

If you order to go, you get a free fried rice or chow mein with purchase of two entrees.
author: Karl N.

description:
No offense to the neighborhoodies who loves this restaurant
or to the Vegetarians who finds their menu full of choices, I am starting to dislike this place. 

The times I went here were out of respect to my dear friend, who chooses this place because she can hardly find vegetarian dim sum elsewhere. So i oblige, but oh my god, don't expect to have your order taken down right or don't expect all your food to come out exactly like you ordered.

They messed up about 4-5 dishes of ours and gave us the wrong drink. We didn't get mad and they didn't apologize. The waiter either has a really weird sense of humor or he was dissing us a lot, we couldn't really tell. Either way, the only time he was interested in our party was when I was going to the bathroom with my purse, because he thought my black purse was the folder for the bill. 

The food is really not worth for anyone to drive there. If you live a block above, that's fine but don't bother if it's going to take you more than 2 minutes to get there.
author: N K.

description:
Fast delivery. Very fast. Used a Delorean and 1.21 jigawatts of power fast. I ordered enough food for over 25 people and it still got there in under 20 minutes.

It didn't hurt that it was tasty to boot, especially the (DELIVERY!) Dim Sum. Did I mention they deliver dim sum?
author: Ryan L.

description:
I got deathly ill food poisoning for 48 hours after eating salt & pepper shrimp from this restaurant. BEWARE!

I'll spare you the details, but it was the worst ever.
author: Scottie L.

description:
This place is so good when you're stoned out of your mind, lying in bed in some stranger's house in the Western Addition while watching Adult Swim.

Vegan Dim Sum.  What more could one ask for?  If memory serves I had some kind of curry thing, some kind of rice ball with fake chicken, oh!  Onion Pancakes.....SO. Good.  I think we ate some kind of curry chow mein.   My only complaint is that I needed to use soy sauce because the food was somewhat healthy and not loaded with sodium.   Give me salt.  If I'm going to smoke a lot of weed and lie in bed watching Mighty Boosh I want to eat something salty.

They deliver.  Even better.  I was afraid to leave the house after 10 because I'm from the suburbs and if memory serves someone got shot in the Western Addition pretty recently.  Guns scare me, but Vegan dim sum makes me brave.
author: Mimi V.

description:
For some strange and terrible reason, I cannot stop thinking about their pork fried rice. I have been thinking about it for a week straight now, and have eaten in nearly every single day of this week. Really, I don't give a fuck about anything else right now. 

"Hey Dave G. is was thinking that"-
"Shhh, I don't give a fuck."

"Dave G. did you hear on the news today"-
"Shhh, I don't give a fuck."

"Mister! Please help me I can't find my mommy and"-
"Shhh, little girl, I don't give a fuck."

Really, this is pretty ridiculous. At first I was getting it delivered but then I began to suspect the driver of eating some of the fried rice on the way over for no good or logical reason, so now I walk over there and watch them make it, and I make sure I get every goddamn grain of rice that's coming to me. God help me.
author: Dave G.

description:
Never been to the actual place to sit down and eat, so my previous experiences at Big Lantern were delivered right to my door. Not bad, for the price and quality and convenience t'was all worth the ducats.

 Last night I decided to join a partay at double dutch but was starved to death and happy to recognize the Lantern 2 stores down from it decided to stuff myself and drag a friend with me.

 Never have I been so humilliated by a waiter in my whole life. He brings the wrong check and tells me it's the correct one after I tell him. Takes our plates before we're done eating and brings the check before asking us if we want desert. I mean; this guy wants us outta there! and if they're closing they should kindly tell us they could only offer to go. I almost puked the food, the waiter standing over my shoulder, Charging $ 7.99 for a side of spinach! a terrible attitude I later pointed out to the manager who has as indifferent as the waiter, and as much as I love their meatless chicken and convenience of having food delivered I will never rely on this place again. 

 Save yourself while you can.

"For if you bake bread with indifference you bake a bitter bread that feeds but half man's hunger" -- Kahlil Gibran
author: Valentina C.

description:
The Big Lantern was highly recommended by a friend so I gave it a try. 

I started with a few options on the dim sum menu both of which I had never tried. One was a spinach and tofu wrap and the other was a veggie tofu roll and both were delicious. For the main course I tried something I had never heard of...Numbing Spicy Mandarin Noodle. The plate came and it was enough to feed an army. I ate 3 plates full of it and still had half the plate to take home.

The prices were great especially given the size of the portions and the service was quick and prompt. Overall I had a great experience at the Big Lantern and will definitely return for more delectable carnage.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Barf.

That's what I did tonight after eating there this afternoon. 

The food was not great but the service was especially terrible. Our pot stickers were brought out after we had almost finished our meal. Our check was also brought out as we were still eating. There were plenty of open tables, yet we were constantly asked if we were finished. Finally, once we were done and on our way out, discussing where to go, the waitress came over again, stepped on my foot and reached over me to get the cash and bill. Really, was that really necessary? 

Avoid, avoid, avoid.
author: tracey m.

description:
When Big Lantern first opened, a couple of us went there in the evening to partake in hot, fresh and delicious dimsum --- what a treat it was to have dimsum in the evening and quite a surprise that it was tasty to boot!

After having way too many bloody marys on an empty stomach during an afternoon at the 500 Club, my boyfriend and I returned to Big Lantern to overload on alcohol-absorbing, inebriation-slowing carbs.  Bad idea.

What happened to their food?  The wor wonton soup tasted great, but was served in a disappointingly tiny cup and cost me a limb.  The lemon chicken was a gigantic piece of fried batter, covered in what looked like an ogre's boogers.  My shrimp with lobster sauce had its delicate flavor killed by all the mushrooms, rather than shrimp, drowning in the egg sauce.  Not good.

Almost $40 poorer, we both walked away completely disappointed and hungry (couldn't eat the food because it was so bad), renaming the restaurant Barf Lantern and vowing to never return. *ick*

UPDATE - 12.10.07
When I started working in Noe Valley, my boss ordered Big Lantern for lunch and it was great!!  I guess the trick is choosing carefully among their dishes.  I HIGHLY recommend their house special spicy fried rice (includes chicken, pork, shrimp, egg, jalepeno, pepper oil ...), kung pao chicken, and some sort of soup with egg, beef and cilantro.

Another thing I have to mention is that the other night when I ordered food to go, I called from outside their restaurant to see if the food was ready yet, and the phone guy actually brought my food outside to me so I didn't have to leave my car.  Since there was no parking in the area, I really appreciated that extra service.  Kudos to Big Lantern for changing my mind!!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Quality Chinese food? NO
Good Chinese food? hmm it's ok

Ironically, I get the craving for Big Lantern whenever I'm hungover.. Today was the case.. While I typically order the sweet & sour pork - which is usually good - today I ordered the dim sum. 

Chicken Siu Mai - decent
Shrimp Dumpling - a little over cooked, decent
Steamed Spare ribs - pretty good...

Good place if you're hungover, bad place if you're craving quality food.
author: Monica S.

description:
Yummy yum dim sum....
So far, never a long wait. Prompt service and the peeps there are nice as nice can be for SF. The food has never been wrong.  I LOVE the taro rolls and the buns of various fillings.  Plus, I'm not a huge seafood fan, so their stuffed crab , etc is not too fishy.  
And the colorful signage outside is...kitschy...sort of.
author: Joyhan S.

description:
So sad. As a Yum Yum default, we had high hopes for Big Lantern. So high. I was willing to ignore other yelpers and hope they just had some Haterade because Yum Yum was closed. Alas, it was not the Haterade. They were right. Big Lantern is just not that good.

We ordered our Yum Yum usual (mongolian beef, bbq pork fried rice), and crossed our fingers. Let me preface that I'm not that picky -- I like me some cheap chinese food. Even sometimes the deep fried bits with sweet, sticky sauce, but this... this was mediocre at best. The Mongolian beef was sweet (!?) and the rice was greasy. I mean, it's fried rice. How hard can that be? Needless to say, we were spoiled by Yum Yum, and much as we wanted it to be, Big Lantern is not an acceptable alternative.

Two stars for customer service. Super nice on the phone and fast delivery. If you can overlook food that is mediocre. (Maybe it's good greasy drunk food? Maybe?)
author: Melissa R.

description:
This place has taken a definite turn for the better once the Yum Yum House staff came over.  I'm still dismayed that Yum Yum lost their lease - I always loved the food at Yum Yum.

I recommend the Mango Chicken, Sesame Chicken, Basil Tofu, Garlic Eggplant, and the Chow Mein.  The lunch plates are very generous and an extremely good value.  I can never finish my whole plate.
author: Bill V.

description:
I think when reviewing things it is important to keep things in perspective.  So this review is for the fact that they offer delivery and is coming from the perspective of a vegan.

At this point, I think this is by far the best Chinese delivery I've had for the '117.  They offer dim sum and a really nice variety of vegan Chinese.  The vegetarian taro puff off the dim sum menu was knock-my-socks-off good.  The spinach dumpling was tasty, the General's meatless chicken was off the chain.  I thought the veggie chow fun was great - the tofu had this really nice meaty texture and was cut in nice thin strips (though it should be noted my boyfriend found the texture of the tofu to be too dry.)

If you're veggie and looking for delivery in the Mission or the '117, this place is about the best you could hope for from delivery - good flavor, satisfying and not overly greasy-gross.

And be sure to get the vegetarian taro puffs!  UNGH.

UPDATE:  I don't even want to talk about how many times I have ordered from here in the past three weeks (answer: 6 *hangs head in shame*)

UPDATE #2:  Okay, this is getting embarrassing...I had to bump it up to five stars because I don't think there is a SINGLE place in San Francisco from whence I have gotten grub more times than Big Lantern (and in only the last four weeks, no less!)  That's not just frequency - I'm talking actual number of meals.  WHAT DOES THIS SAY ABOUT ME????  Plus, I FINALLY got myself to switch orders and the sesame meatless chicken is my new go-to order, EVEN better than the General Tso's meatless chicken.  Being a delivery Chinese food place that has vegan options deserves five stars, there is just such a dearth of vegan delivery, esp. to Hayes and Fillmore (see my very depressing list: http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=gqBg-J6nUqL6zw-2THvN0A) 

Oh and then there are those little fried taro puffs.  Eff me, I HONESTLY CANNOT CONTROL MYSELF AROUND THOSE THINGS.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Good grief. Did Big Lantern bribe nearly every other Yelper who has reviewed this piece of dumps. Honestly, if I participated in a taste test between Kibbles and Bits dog food and Big Lantern's most celebrated entree, I'm quite certain I would be unable to tell them apart. 

Bland. Uninspired. Terrible. Crappy as shit. Unsophisticated. The aforementioned describes the dog food Big Lantern tried to pawn off as Chinese take out that I ordered the other day. Not even Tom Hanks in Castaway would eat this junk. He would rather eat his volleyball, Wilson. 

The only positive about Big Lantern is that $18 will get you about 3 lbs of dog food not even your dog would eat. Also, the delivery guy was unnaturally friendly. He kept saying good-bye over and over again, prompting me to reciprocate awkwardly while trying to shut the door. Fortunately for himself, he finally departed before I had a chance to sample the wares. 

To sum things up, I can't imagine anyone has ever ordered Big Lantern more than once. It's not the absolute worst Chinese I've ever had, but it's close. Oh wait, now I'm just blatantly lying. Big Lantern is miserable.
author: Tom C.

description:
I hate to say I have to add my voice to the chorus of "this is no Yum Yum House."

At Yum Yum I would always order the garlic eggplant and the meatless five-flavored chicken--we ordered the garlic eggplant and the sesame meatless chicken (not sure if five-flavor chicken is "general chicken" on the Big Lantern menu?).

The garlic eggplant was not the same--the sauce was much more bland and lacked that certain "I don't know what" that Yum Yum's eggplant had.

The Meatless Sesame Chicken was pretty good, but the meatless nuggets were more like meatballs and less like pieces of chicken.  It did come with really fresh broccoli though.

Overall Big Lantern was just okay, and if not for the comparisons to our dearly departed Yum Yum House, it might have seemed even better. Would go back to try the Dim Sum and see if the general's chicken compares to Yum Yum's five flavor chicken.  Not holding my breath, though I'm sure it'll do in a pinch.
author: Kevin H.

description:
I like this place for so many reasons:

- They deliver, so on those weeknights when we're busy or tired or lazy, they are just a phone call away.

- They have brown rice -- a nice alternative.

- They have lots of veggie options. If you're into the vegetarian meats, they offer that. Great for when we have vegetarian guests over.

- The dim sum is pretty good. Their turnip cake is awesome!

- The menu is extensive and there are very few things on the menu that we haven't liked.

- The prices are fairly reasonable.
author: Joel A.

description: Big Lantern is definitely of the better places for dim sum outside of Chinatown. It seems a lot of people had bad experiences with takeout, and through a 3rd party (with their caps lock key stuck in a downward position), which is unfortunate. It's a neighborhood Chinese restaurant, not haute cuisine on the Rive Gauche. We go there every other week or so for our dim sum fix when we're too lazy to get across town. We haven't, and would not, try takeout in this neighborhood. The food is good, and if you venture to other plates on the menu, like the pineapple fried rice, it tends to be a good value and pretty decent food (speaking as someone who worked in a Chinese restaurant back in the day).  We usually walk away with enough leftovers for another meal later. I recommend this place to my friends for casual dining, especially those who haven't had good dim sum.
author: D S.

description: Love this place! If you are looking for a cheap and yummy night out, look no further. Very large menu and very vegan friendly.
author: Clay W.

description:
I'm determined to log all my eating experiences in SF for the two weeks I am here. I have made a promise to myself that I will also eat out once a day.

That being said, I came home from work utterly tired and not knowing anywhere in the Potrero HIll area to get food.

Big Lantern was the only place I called who was courteous and also didn't take two hours to deliver the food. 

I ordered Mongolian Beef, chicken wings, and a small Hot & Sour soup. The food was still hot and the delivery guy wasn't ratty or pushy. I tipped him five bucks and was satisfied with the meal. It wasn't great, but it wasn't awful, either. The Mongolian Beef had the rice noodles but was a little too gravy-ish for me. The flavor was good and had lots of onions in it. 

The chicken wings were so-so, and the soup was too spicy and bland.
author: emi s.

description: Ordered delivery 10pm Friday night, took about an hour and fifteen minutes. No big deal, it is Friday night after all. Ordered garlic eggplant, beef stew with spinach, and brown rice. Got orange eggplant (or at least that's what it tasted like), beef stew (as ordered), white rice, and fried rice. A little random. None of it was above average.
author: Anna F.

description:
#1 There is no flavor to any of their food.  I have tried it 3 times.  No more.


#2 They also false advertise their prices.  I ordered off the online menu and it ended up costing $2.50 more than it says online when I arrived.  There excuse was  "Thats our old menu"....   Then the price came to like $8.03 and I didnt have the .03 cents and she said "thats ok"  so i figured she was going to spot me the .03 cents.... NOPE  She gave me .97 cents in change.  Thats fine but after ripping me off with the false advertising, not cool.  Then I get home and the food its awful.  Again.

#3 I saw a guy who obviously had a bad cold coughing onto the palate of all the chop stix and forks.  Then watched him put them on each table.
author: Shawn L.

description:
Good Chinese food for next to nothing.

My favorite is the curry, the lemon-grass is good too. I found some orange dish to sweet for me. Waiters provide nice service.
author: Lion K.

description:
Dude wtf,

We have eaten here many many times. 

Tonight however will change our pattern of ordering from Big Lantern . The waiter who answered the phone was a total asshole. He was yelling at us to speak up, and told us we were taking to long to place our order. Um I dont think we had even been on the phone for 15 seconds before he started yelling at us to hurry up. Who does that. Its not like we called and THEN decided what we wanted to eat. We had our list and was ready to go, I guess this wasnt good enough.  Who yells at customers? Actual yelling, not  just rasing his voice but actually yelling. 

We have no patients for bullshit like this. If I could give no stars, I would. We hung up the phone and ordered from OSHA instead. 

never again big lantern
author: Molly C.

description:
I got take out/pick up and this review is only for the fried rice.

I finally decided to try this place. I don't usually eat at Chinese restaurants because I can make my own Chinese food, but sometimes I just die for fried rice that is cooked over a huge flame and a big wok. It makes all the difference in the world in the texture of the rice and egg.

I got the Pork Fried Rice, which was $7.12. I thought it was going to be $5.50 plus tax! Their menu prices are old. Anyway, the pork was bbq pork (yum, yum), and the rice was packed to the brim in the to-go takeout box and piping hot. The flavor was good. Lots of soy sauce (which isn't that bad, but I prefer a tiny less) and it seemed to have a sweetness to it. MSG? Sweetness from the pork? Not sure. The fried rice was definitely very greasy; I've had less greasy fried rice elsewhere.

The inside of the restaurant is actually quite nice. On the outside it looks pretty cruddy.

Service on the phone was interesting...:
Me: Hi, can I order for pick up?
Guy: Yes, what's your numa;dfkjaf?
Me: What? Did you ask me for my phone number?
Guy: Hold on
[puts me on hold for 5 seconds]
Guy: Hi, what is your phone number?
[I give him my phone number]
Guy: What is your name?
Me: Angela
Guy: What do you want?
Me: Pork fried rice and that's it.
Guy: What is your phone number?....it will cost....ok 15 minutes. Bye.

I will come back here for more fried rice. I don't do dim sum or other dishes unless I know for sure that the place is excellent.
author: Angela H.

description:
I was leery when someone suggested we go to Big Lantern.  I mean, come on, Chinese food, much less dim sum, in the Mission?  It didn't help when we got seated and I took a look around - only Mission yuppie white couples.  Oh great.  What do *they* know about Chinese food, anyway, I thought to myself.

It ended fine though.  The assorted dim sum was freshly steamed and wasn't so bad (though the shui mai was definitely only a 3).  The Chef's Special Mandarin clay pot is what pushed Big Lantern from 3 to 4 stars though.  Fresh veggies, good assortment of meat and seafood, good sauce.  I'd probably do some take-out from here.
author: Wendy T.

description: After a long hiatus from Big Lantern (a few too many bad meals turned us off), we tried it again last night.  A mistake.  Sizzling rice soup was inedibly salty.  Really.  Chow mein was tasteless.  Our old standby fried rice completely disappointed.  The only thing worth eating were the sesame balls.  Goodbye again, Big Lantern.
author: Littles F.

description:
There are a few restaurants that are special to me.
...part of it is consistency of a mood as well as the food.
This place is one of them.
